note_models.name: Cloze

fields:
PITUITARY GLAND

Where is it located?{{c1::sella tunica at base of skull between eyes anteriorly}}

The hypothalamus is continuous with the {{c1::posterior}} pituitary gland

So what would be the difference in how hypothalamus communicates with either lobe of the pituitary?
{{c1::post, communicate directly, it is continuous
Anterior, communicates through hypophyseal portal system}}

The hypothalamus releases {{c1::neuropeptide}} which causes the release of hormones from the ant. pituitary gland. This is normally released in a {{c1::pulsatile/diurnal}} pattern.

Hormone released by hypothalamus/ hormone reeleased by Ant pituatary/ Hormone released by gland as a result

GnRH/{{c1::LH+FSH}}/{{c1::Testosterone and estradiol}}
{{c1::CRF}}/ACTH/{{c1::Cortisol}}
{{c1::TRH}}/{{c1::TSH}}/Thyroid Hormone

And GHRH causes release of {{c1::Growth hormone}}

{{c1::Dopamine}} causes the tonic inhibition of release of {{c1::prolactin}} from ant pituitary
{{c1::Somatostatin}} causes the tonic and controlled inhibition of release of {{c1::growth hormone}} from ant pituitary

The posterior pituitary gland releases {{c1::oxytocin and aVP/ADH}}

Pituitary Tumours:

{{c1::80}}% are non-functioning tumours, how do they effect the pituitary gland?
{{c1::compress and cause hormonal dysfunction or inhibition of the release of the hormones}}

Functioning tumours: 
ACTH producing tumour causes {{c1::Cushing's disease}}
GH producing tumour causes {{c1::Acromegaly or pituitary gigantism}}
Secretory Gonadotropinomas causes {{c1::too much LH and FSH}}
TSHoma causes {{c1::hyperthyroidism}}
Prolactinomas ccause {{c1::too much prolactin}}

HYPERPROLACTINAEMIA: Excessive Prolactin

SOURCES:

Functional tumours:
Microprolactinoma causes {{c1::1500-5000}}prolactin levels
Macroprolactinoma cuases {{c1::>5000}} prolactin levels

How might a non-functional tumour cause it?
{{c1::Tumour compresses pituitary stalk, inhibiting dopamine transport to the pituitary}}
What prolactin levels does this cause?{{c1::>1500}}

Drug Induced:
Name three drug types that would cause it
{{c1::dopamine antagonists, anti-psychotics, antiemetics}}
What particular function on a particular receptor would cause it?
{{c1::inhibition of D2 receptor}}

Name two other causes:
{{c1::STRESS-INDUCED
PREGNANCY / BREAST FEEDING}}


The prolactin receptor is a type of {{c1::GH}} receptor, dimerizes when prolactin binds.

Give two functions of this receptor
{{c1::trophic effect on breast tissue and production of milk (STAT5) signalling}}
{{c1::Increase in efficient fuel utilisation and glucose coming into cell (Akt)}}

Unfortunately, when there is too much it inhibits the GnRH neuron in the hypothalamus
What is the outcome of this?
{{c1::Causes inhibition of GnRH which causes Hypogonadism due to the inhibition of LH and FSH which cuases less testosterone and progesterone}}
{{c1::}}



Clinical Problems

Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism:
{{c1::Anovulation / Infertility}}
{{c1::â†“ Libido}}
{{c1::Erectile Dysfunction}}in men
{{c1::Osteoporosis due lack of estradiol}} in women

Galactorrhoea: {{c1::production of breast milk in men and women}}

Pressure Effects:
{{c1::
Pituitary Adenoma 
Headache 
Bi-temporal Visual Field Defect}}(3)


MEDICAL MANAGEMENT

Contraceptive pill
Hormone Replacement therapy, what hormone? {{c1::Dopamine, if you said prolactin you deserve to fail this exam}}

Very rarely surgical debulking

Dopamine Agonist therapy:

Two drugs
What is their drug class? {{c1::Ergot Alkaloids}}
What is their 5-HT2A mediated adverse affect thta has to be checked on every 5 years?
{{c1::right sided valvular disease}}

{{c1::Bromocriptine}}
t1/2 2-8 hours
3 times a day dosage
Adverse effects:
Nausea 
Postural Hypotension 
CNS side effects that end up being severly limiting
Can be used during pregnancy

{{c1::Cabergoline}}
4 times more potent
T1/2 65 hours
1-2 weekly
Less side effects and better clinical response
What is a side effect it has?
{{c1::Behavioural abnormalities, higher risk taking}}


REDUCED PROLACTIN IN >{{c1::90}}% CASES
REDUCED TUMOUR BULK IN >{{c1::70}}% CASES

GROWTH HORMONE
Can you guess what factor almost all growth hormones actions are mediated by?{{c1::IGF-1}}

What is GH signalling pathway mediated by?{{c1::JAK-2}}

The effects of GH:

1. In bones:{{c1::increases osteoclastic activity which promotes bone mineralisation and turnover}}

2. In muscles:{{c1::Muscle growth and differentiation}}

3.Adipocytes:{{c1::Pre-adipocyte to adipocyte differentiation and fat storage}}

4.In kidneys: {{c1::Increases Glomerular Filtration Rate}}

5. Liver has a range of functions

6. Promotes acral growth and soft tissue expansion

7. Increases expression of {{c1::glucose transporter}}

GH DEFICIENCY

Most common Ant pituitary hormone deficiency

The treatment is {{c1::rhGH (replacement Growth hormone)}}
It is administered {{c1::subcutaneously}}
Circulating T1/2 {{c1::20mins}}
Biological T1/2 {{c1::17 hours}}

Dosage?{{c1::once daily}}

Do you give it to children?
{{c1::yes, it is needed for good bone growth and getting to their height}}

DO you give it to adults?
{{c1::Braitheann sÃ©, if their AGHDA(QoL) score improves then yes,
if it doesn't after six months then no}}

How do you monitor therapy?{{c1::Monitor therapy with serum IGF-1 concentration}}

Growth Hormone Excess

What are the general effects of too much growth hormone?
{{c1::Insulin}} resistance
Intracranial {{c1::hyper}}tension
Arthralgia / myalgia: {{c1::muscle and joint pain}}
{{c1::Carpal tunnel}} syndrome
Muscle,{{c1::atrophy}}
Osteoporosis

And the one that usually eventually kills you, {{c1::dilated cardiomyopathy}}

What is the physiological difference between pituitary gigantism and accromegaly?{{c1::Gigantism occurs before epiphyseal plates closes, tumour is arge enough to compress pituitary and cause hypogonadism, Acromegaly occurs after so cannot stimulate longitudinal growth so extremities get bigger}}

Acromegaly Symptoms:
Macroglossia {{c1::large tongue}}
Large Hands/Feet
Prognathism{{c1::protrusion of lower jaw}}
Skin Tags
Bowel hamartomas{{c1::benign tumours of the bowel}}
Cardiomyopathy
Obstructive Sleep Apnoea
Type 2 diabetes
Osteoporosis
Osteoarthrits

Gigantism symptoms;
All that but an additional one {{c1::growth can also be longitudinal}}

Treatment of Growth Hormone Excess

What hormone anologue would you use to inhibit the release of Growth Hormone {{c1::somatostatin}}

What receptors in particular would you target?{{c1::SSTR 2 and 5}}

They inhibit GH secretion and reduce tumour size

These hormone analogues

Administered {{c1::subcutaneously}}

Short-acting
{{c1::short acting octreotide}}
100% bioavailability
Peak - 30 minutes
T1/2 - 90 minutes
Duration of action 12 hours approximately

Long Acting
{{c1::Microsphere bound preparation (octreotide)
Gel preparation (Lanreotide)}}(2)
Circulates for 2 - 3 weeks
Slow release of hormone from spheres
Intramuscular Injection fortnightly

Side effects of these
{{c1::GI Upset}} - 50%
{{c1::Gallstones}} - 25%
{{c1::Diabetes Mellitus}} - <5%
Local skin reactions

What else can they be used for?
{{c1::Neuroendocrine tumours
Acute Variceal Bleeding
Splanchnic vasoconstriction
TSHoma}}(4)

You can also inhibit the Growth hormone receptor using 
{{c1::Pegvisomant}}
Subcutaneous administration
Daily injection
Titrated to IGF-1

Does this cure the condition?{{c1::No, only treats symptoms, may actually increase tumour size, due to decrease in IGF-1}}
